msgSnippet: ... I also extended JUnit to count the assertions and had to modify the Assert.java file.  I then wrote the test in the TestAssert.java file and it worked
messageBody:
> We are extending JUnit a bit to display a count of assertions
> encountered when running a suite of tests. We can get this to work
> (i.e. to display the correct number of assertions encountered), but
> we want to do it right by having tests for this extension in JUnit
> itself. We want to write a test like this:

I also extended JUnit to count the assertions and had to modify the
Assert.java file. I then wrote the test in the TestAssert.java file and
it worked fine. Maybe you're testing where it's harder to do.

> (inside TestCaseTest)
> public void testAssertionCount() {
> TestCase assertionCount = new TestCase("assertionCount") {
> protected void runTest() {
> }
> public void testAssertionCount(){
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue("",true);
> assertEquals(true,true);
> assertEquals("",true,true);
> }
> };
> verifyAssertionCount(assertionCount);
> }

I would code something like that:

public void testAssertionCount () {
setAssertCount(0); // reset the assertions' counter
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue("",true);
assertEquals(true,true);
assertEquals("",true,true);
assertTrue("Wrong assertion #", 4 == assertCount());
}

I assume that the setAssertCount and assertCount methods are accessible
within a TestCase (which makes sense). In my case they are defined in
the Assert class.

Vladimir
